questions.question: President Donald Trump returned to the White House after treatment in Walter Reed Hospital for which disease?

imageMetadata.altText: President Donald Trump poses on a White House balcony after returning from Walter Reed Hospital.
imageMetadata.resources:
President Donald Trump poses atop the Truman Balcony of the White House after taking off his protective face mask as he returns to the White House after being hospitalized at Walter Reed Medical Center for coronavirus disease (COVID-19) treatment, in Washington D.C. Oct. 5, 2020. REUTERS/Erin Scott/File Photo

Additional resource: "News Roundup: Measuring COVID response as it spreads through White House" via PBS NewsHour EXTRA https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/daily-videos/news-roundup-measuring-covid-response-as-it-spreads-through-white-house/

questions.title: 7 million Americans have been diagnosed with COVID
questions.description: Scientists and public health officials say the U.S. can do these three things to stop COVID: 1) Clear, consistent messaging about COVID from political leaders 2) mask up 3) contact tracing

questions.question: Do you think people should wear masks in public?

choices.answer: YES, but there should be no law requiring it.

imageMetadata.altText: A young girl in Chinatown in New York City wears a surgical mask on a city street.

questions.question: Democrat nominee Joe Biden supports keeping the Affordable Care Act which provides health care to millions of Americans.

imageMetadata.altText: Joe Biden speaks to the press in New Castle, Del., before he boards his campaign plane to Miami.
imageMetadata.resources: U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden speaks to the press pool at REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

questions.resources: U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden speaks to the press pool at REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

questions.title: 2020 Election Issue: Affordable Care Act
questions.description: Biden and Trump have very different opinions on health care. Biden supports the Affordable Care Act (a.k.a. Obamacare) while Trump would like to repeal it.
questions.resources: PBS NewsHour's Yamiche Alcindor and Lisa Desjardins explain the health care policies of President Donald Trump and Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden. https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/with-health-care-a-top-issue-for-voters-what-do-biden-and-trump-propose

questions.question: Do you think the government should provide health care to people who cannot afford it?

choices.answer: YES, but only to a certain point.
Government should provide everyone with health care no matter their income.

imageMetadata.altText: Demonstrators hold signs in support of the Affordable Care Act before a protest in Philadelphia.
imageMetadata.resources: Demonstrators hold signs in support of the Affordable Care Act at a gathering before the start of a protest march near the hotel where House and Senate Republicans are attending a retreat, in Philadelphia, Penn., Jan. 25, 2017. REUTERS/Tom Mihalek

questions.resources: Demonstrators hold signs in support of the Affordable Care Act at a gathering before the start of a protest march near the hotel where House and Senate Republicans are attending a retreat, in Philadelphia, Penn., Jan. 25, 2017. REUTERS/Tom Mihalek

questions.question: What is the correct order of events from newest to oldest?

choices.answer: President Trump promises to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
President Obama signs the Affordable Care Act into law.
President Lyndon B. Johnson signs Medicare and Medicaid into law.
President Roosevelt signs the Social Security Bill into law.

imageMetadata.altText: Applications are seen at a rally of the Affordable Care Act in Jackson, Mississippi.

REUTERS/Jonathan Bachman

questions.title: What are Medicare and Medicaid?
questions.description: Medicare and Medicaid were established more than 50 years ago and cover the health care needs of more than 120 million Americans. Politicians debate long-term sustainability of the programs while the vast majority of Americans support them.
questions.resources: This PBS NewsHour story aired on Jul 29, 2015. "After 50 years, how do we ensure Medicare and Medicaid longevity?" Full video and transcript: https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/after-50-years-how-do-we-ensure-medicare-and-medicaid-longevity#transcript

imageMetadata.altText: Driver Donavan Dunn loads young Maddie Holt who uses a wheelchair into the van for an appointment.
imageMetadata.resources: Driver Donavan Dunn loads Maddie Holt into the van on Nov. 21, 2017. The only way Maddie and her mother, Meagan Holt, can make the trip to the hospital is by using a service provided by Medicaid called non-emergency medical transportation, or NEMT. (Heidi de Marco/KHN)

questions.title: Three More Key Issues in 2020
questions.description: From an August 2020 poll, 47% of voters said President Donald Trump would better handle the economy than Democrat nominee Joe Biden (45%). The majority of Americans said Biden would do a better job over Trump on COVID and race relations.

imageMetadata.altText: A poll chart from August 2020 shows how voters think the candidates would handle four issues.
imageMetadata.resources:
The chart appeared in the NewsHour article, "Trust in Trump sinks over COVID-19 as Biden support grows," by Laura Sanatham. On the issues of who could better handle the economy, more voters said President Donald Trump would handle the issue of the economy better than Democrat nominee Joe Biden. On the pandemic and race relations, the majority of Americans said they believed Biden would do a better job over Trump. The poll was conducted by the PBS NewsHour, NPR and Marist in August 2020. The chart was created by Megan McGrew/PBS NewsHour. Story link:
https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/more-americans-trust-biden-than-trump-to-handle-the-pandemic

questions.resources:

questions.title: What issues matter most to young people?
questions.description: Key issues for young people include health care, the economy and education. Young Republicans say they care more about immigration reform and young Democrats say they care more about climate change, according to the Alliance for Youth Action.

imageMetadata.altText: A youth holds up a "Now We Vote" sign as they take part in a National School Walkout march.
